dublin_core.dcvalue: Objectives This study aimed to identify the active compounds in Oldenlandia diffusa OD decoction and the compounds absorbed into plasma and to determine whether the absorbed compounds derived from OD exerted any anti inflammatory effects in rats with collagen induced arthritis CIA Methods The UPLC PDA Ultra Performance Liquid Chromatography Photo Diode Array method was applied to identify the active compounds both in the decoction and rat plasma The absorbable compound was administered to the CIA rats and the effects were dynamically observed X ray films of the joints and HE stain of synovial tissues were analyzed The levels of IL 1 and TNF in the rats from each group were measured by means of ELISA The absorbed compound in the plasma of CIA rats was identified as ferulic acid FA following OD decoction administration Two weeks after the administration of FA solution or OD decoction the general conditions improved compared to the model group The anti inflammatory effect of FA was inferior to that of the OD decoction P Under 0 05 based on a comparison of IL 1 TNF levels FA from the OD decoction was absorbed into the body of CIA rats where it elicited anti inflammatory responses in rats with CIA Conclusions These results suggest that FA is the bioactive compound in OD decoction and FA exerts its effects through anti inflammatory pathways
Evidence-based complementary and alternative medicine : eCAM
Anti-Inflammatory Effects of the Bioactive Compound Ferulic Acid Contained in Oldenlandia diffusa on Collagen-Induced Arthritis in Rats.
